question.title: Switch Statement
question.content:
Given a number a, you have to use a switch statement to print "One" if the given number is equal to 1, "Two" if the number is 2, and so on till 9 ("Nine") else print "Unknown".

Note: Print the statements without quotes.

Examples:

Input: a = 10
Output: Unknown
Input: a = 1
Output: One

rephrased.body: Given an integer `a`, use a switch statement to determine its corresponding word representation. If `a` is between 1 and 9 (inclusive), print the English word for that number (e.g., 1 -> One, 2 -> Two, ..., 9 -> Nine). If `a` is outside this range, print "Unknown".

testcases.explanation: The input 10 is outside the range of 1 to 9, so the output is 'Unknown'.
The input 1 corresponds to the word 'One'.
The input 5 corresponds to the word 'Five'.
The input 9 corresponds to the word 'Nine'.
The input -1 is outside the range of 1 to 9, so the output is 'Unknown'.

hints:
Java:

Inside switch(number) create case 1 in which we will print one and also create default case in which we will print Not One.

CPP:

Inside switch(number) create case 1 in which we will print one and also create default case in which we will print Not One.


â€‹C:

Inside switch(number) create case 1 in which we will print one and also create default case in which we will print Not One.
